review.title: NdFluents: A Multi-dimensional Contexts Ontology
review.abstract: Annotating semantic data with metadata is becoming more and more important to provide information about the statements being asserted. While initial solutions proposed a data model to represent a specific dimension of meta-information (such as time or provenance), the need for a general annotation framework which allows representing different context dimensions is needed. In this paper, we extend the 4dFluents ontology by Welty and Fikes---on associating temporal validity to statements---to any dimension of context, and discuss possible issues that multidimensional context representations have to face and how we address them.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: In knowledge representation, it is often necessary to characterize the context associated with a statement, such as when and how it was generated, or who uttered it. However, RDF and OWL can only natively represent binary relations [12]. Many models exist to provide statements about statements, some of which are specific to a particular "dimension" of the context, such as temporal validity. Along these lines, Welty and Fikes [17] proposed an ontology to describe flows (i.e. entities whose characteristics change over time) in 2006. Their approach has improved the state of art in temporal representation and has been used and expanded in other works, but it deals only with one dimension that characterizes a statement. Nevertheless, Welty and Fikes's approach can be expanded so that any number of context dimensions can be represented before we present these context dimensions through a generic ontology that can extend to any specific dimension of the context.

sections.heading: 2. 4dFluents Ontology
sections.text: Welty and Fikes [17] deal with the problem of representing fluid relations, i.e. relations held within a certain time interval and not in others. They deal with the problem from the perspective of diachronic identity (i.e., how a unit looks different at different times) and show the two different ways of approaching it: • The permanent (3D) view distinguishes between endurants, endurants that are always present throughout its existence, and perdurants, events that affect an entity during a certain period of time during the entity's existence. • The permanent (4D) view argues that entities themselves must be treated as permanent, i.e. temporal parts of a four-dimensional meta-entity. Instead of making a claim about some entities, such as "Paris is the capital of France," the assertion about its temporal parts should be considered as fluid: "A temporary part of Paris (since 508 until now) is the capital part of an entity that has been expressed since the 50s."

sections.heading: 3.2. Dealing with Datatype Properties
sections.text: The original 4dFluents ontology does not provide information for modeling data type properties. While there is nothing to prevent the use of regular data type properties with context-related parts of an entity, it may be desirable to explain explicit axioms for context properties to facilitate arguing about this information. In this case, the statements of Ontology 5 must be added to the NdFluents ontology. Figure 2 shows an example in which a context-related property is used to specify the population of Paris at a certain time interval. sections.heading: 3.4. Relations between Different ContextualParts
sections.text: NdFluents ontology is so advanced that it can model relationships between different contextual parts of different contexts (i.e., a temporary part of Paris could be the capital of a provenance part of France). While this may be convenient for individual cases, it is necessary for a contextual property that relates to the same dimension of the context. In this case, it is necessary to add the corresponding axioms to ontology. In Ontology 8 we show the axioms needed to relate this property to the Temporal Parts. sections.heading: 3.5. Adapting Non-Contextual Ontologies to NdFluents
sections.text: In the previous sections, we show how to define and use NdFluents to define properties applicable to contextual parts. However, in some cases, we would prefer to reuse existing ontologies. It is not always possible to add a co-ownership relationship between an already defined property and a contextual property, since most of the restrictions do not apply to the contextual parts of an entity. For example, suppose that the property capitalOf Domain City exists and we use it as a flowing property of an entity with the same object, then one would conclude that Paris @ 1 is a city rather than Paris being derived as a city. There might also be a problem if an InverseFunctionalObjectProperty is used in two different contextual parts of an entity with the same object (e.g. Paris @ 508 and Paris @ 2016, both as capital of France), because they would then be traced back to the same entity.

sections.heading: 3.6. Dealing with Terminological Statements
sections.text: Generally, contexts are used only for assertions (which is usually referred to as ABox), but there are cases where terminological statements (the TBox) can also be considered under other contextual dimensions. Consider the case of classic biological kingdoms. While in the US it is traditionally assumed that there are six kingdoms (Animalia, Plantae, Fungi, Protista, Archaea / Archaeabacteria and Bacteria / Eubacteria), in many other countries only five are considered (Animalia, Plantae, Fungi, Protista and Monera). This classification evolved from the historical perspective of animal and plant kingdoms, while newer classifications include up to eight kingdoms. Whether viruses are included in the taxonomy is still an ongoing debate. Such a classification would subclassify relationships such as haloarchaea subclassifications of Archaeabacteria and Haloarchaea subclassifications of Monera, but it is not dependent on the subclassification of them.

sections.heading: 4. NdFluents in Practice
sections.text: In this section, we will concretize the information so far on the actual steps for the practical implementation of NdFluents ontology, focusing on the decisions to be made in each step and our recommendation. Subsequently, we will show an actual implementation of NdFluents ontology for a concrete set of data with different context dimensions following these steps.

sections.text: In this section, the NdFluents ontology is used as a practical example with two contextual dimensions: The estimated development of the earth's population according to different sources, which requires temporal and provencal dimensions. For this task, we use the information modeled by Wikipedia3.We to capture the steps for temporal and provencal dimensions defined in the previous section. sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: We have proposed NdMarie, a multi-domain contextual representation based on the ontology of 4dFluents. To our knowledge, this is the first generic extension of 4dFluents for any number of contextual dimensions. This representation is to be extended in a modular way for any desired contextual dimension in ontology. We have discussed various possible models that can be used in combining different dimensions, possible additions that can be considered depending on the data we want to represent, and open questions of ontology. We have also provided schematic guidelines for the use of NdFluents and a practical example. Both the ontology and the example are published for public use. While NdFluents requires the inclusion of more three-dimensional data and seems less intuitive than any of the alternatives, it allows a more complete OWL inference within a context (with the exceptions presented in the section).
